occurrences.line_text: That quite smit off his arme, as he it vp did lift.
That your victorious arme will not yet cease,
Which doen he gan aloft t'aduance his arme,
Lanc't through the arme, fell down with him in drerie swound.
Armed to point, sought backe to turne againe;
In wouen maile all armed warily,
Ne fleshly brest can armed be so sound,
An armed knight towards them gallop fast,
The dead corse of an armed knight was spred,
An armed knight, that towards him fast ran,
An armed knight, of bold and bounteous grace,
And deadly hew, an armed corse did lye,
When as againe he armed felt his hond;
Twise sixteen warders sat, all armed bright
Armed with darts of sensuall delight,
But fairest knight aliue, when armed was her brest.
An armed knight, vpon a courser strong,
For th'one was armed all in warlike wize,
Two armed Knights, that toward them did pace,
An armed Knight vnder a forrest side,
Where on the Bridge he ready armed saw
Of which the one him seem'd a Knight all armed,
Of armed men, comming with close intent
Two Knights, all armed ready for to fight,
Both armed Knights, and eke vnarmed rout:
Of knights and armed men, which did maintaine
The armed knights stopping his passage by,
Ne ought auayled for the armed knight,
Nathelesse him selfe he armed all in hast,
The armed Prince, with shield so blazing bright,
All armed in a cote of yron plate,
Against an armed knight, that did on horsebacke ryde.
That armed knight, that low on ground he lay;
For armed knight a wight vnarm'd to wrong.
An armed Knight approaching to the place,
He goth on foote all armed by her side,
He chaunst far off an armed Knight to spy,
The which were armed both agreeably,
Had vnderneath, him armed priuily.
That terrifide his foes, and armed him,
The fift Armeddan, skild in louely layes;
From th'vtmost brinke of the Armericke shore,
Y cladd in mightie armes and siluer shielde,
Yet armes till that time did he neuer wield:
Without regard of armes and dreaded fight:
In mighty armes he was yclad anon,
Their armes abroad, with gray mosse ouercast,
A knight her met in mighty armes embost,
And feates of armes did wisely vnderstand.
Young knight, what euer that dost armes professe,
Whereas an errant knight in armes ycled,
Of fortune false, and oddes of armes in field.
And eke enchaunted armes, that none can perce,
In sun-bright armes, and battailous array:
T'obserue the sacred lawes of armes, that are assynd.
With which the armes, that earst so bright did show,
From her nigh wearie waine, and in her armes
Whom hauing softly disarayd of armes,
He had in armes abroad wonne muchell fame,
And lull in rugged armes, withouten childish feare.
But had he beene, where earst his armes were lent,
So willingly she came into his armes,
For this young Prince, when first to armes he fell;
His rawbone armes, whose mighty brawned bowrs
That with his glistring armes does ill agree;
But he of rope or armes has now no memoree.
Of puissant armes, and laid in easie bed;
But deeds of armes must I at last be faine,
What need of armes, where peace doth ay remaine,
And proue thy puissaunt armes, as seemes thee best became.
Those glistring armes, that heauen with light did fill,
That I this man of God his godly armes may blaze.
But thought his armes to leaue, and helmet to vnlace.
With heat, toyle, wounds, armes, smart, & inward fire
Of tall young men, all hable armes to sownd,
For by the faith, which I to armes haue plight,
When armes he swore, and streight did enterpris
His warlike armes about him gan embrace,
That decks and armes your shield with faire defence:
Till he his armes about her sides gan fold,
And with bold furie armes the weakest hart;
The little babe vp in his armes he hent;
But his sad fathers armes with bloud defilde,
Since errant armes to sew he first began;
Whilst thus they mingled were in furious armes,
Is this the ioy of armes? be these the parts
Themselues of soiled armes, and to prepare
His puissaunt armes about his noble brest,
Should need of all his armes, him to defend;
Through deedes of armes and prowesse martiall;
Abroad in armes, at home in studious kind
Thought in his bastard armes her to embrace.
As feates of armes, and loue to entertaine,
Of armes was wont to fight, yet nathemoe
In his strong armes he stiffely him embraste,
One in bright armes embatteiled full strong,
Thereby thine armes seeme stro[n]g, but manhood fraile;
That he in ods of armes was conquered;
And hong their conquered armes for more defame
His pricking armes, entrayld with roses red,
And called for his armes; for he would algates fight.
Where noyse of armes, or vew of martiall guize
Not this rude kind of battell, nor these armes
Then of their armes: Mars is Cupidoes frend,
Delighting all in armes and cruell warre,
But with his raging armes he rudely flasht,
Me ill besits, that in der-doing armes,
Faire shields, gay steedes, bright armes be my delight:
Sheilds, steeds, and armes, & all things for thee meet
But mucky filth his braunching armes annoyes,
But I in armes, and in atchieuements braue,
Glistring in armes and battailous aray,
Soone as those glitterand armes he did espye,
With him in bloudie armes they rashly did debate.
I will him reaue of armes, the victors hire,
Th'enchaunter by his armes and amenaunce,
The law of armes, to strike foe vndefide.
Twixt his two mighty armes engrasped fast,
Oppressours powre by armes and puissant hond?
That sith I armes and knighthood first did plight,
Both in his armes, and crowne, and by that draught
And taking armes, the Britons to her drew;
Eftsoones himselfe in glitterand armes he dight,
Glistring in armes and warlike ornament,
The Squire arriuing, fiercely in his armes
Twixt his two mightie armes him vp he snatcht,
And of his armes despoyled easily,
Ouer the waues his rugged armes doth lift,
His brawnie armes, and all his body straine,
His tyred armes for toylesome wearinesse,
That art in mighty armes most magnifide
Therefore, Sir knight, your ready armes about you throw.
He hearkned, and his armes about him tooke,
Their clasping armes, in wanton wreathings intricate.
Low his lasciuious armes adown did creepe,
His warlike armes, the idle instruments
From seeking praise, and deeds of armes abrode,
For neuer yet, sith warlike armes he bore,
Ne armes to beare against the others syde:
And yet in armes Noctante greater grew:
And to the troubled chamber all in armes did throng.
And her bright armes about her body dight:
To whom no share in armes and cheualrie
Yet sith they warlike armes haue layd away:
All my delight on deedes of armes is set,
What shape, what shield, what armes, what steed, what sted,
Achilles armes, which Arthegall did win.
Betwixt her feeble armes her quickly keight,
So hauing said, her twixt her armes twaine
Long time ye both in armes shall beare great sway,
And ciuile armes to exercise no more:
That now all Britanie doth burne in armes bright.
Let vs in feigned armes our selues disguize,
Of warlike armes in her forthwith they tynd,
Beside those armes there stood a mighty speare,
She might in equall armes accompany,
Ne euer dofte her armes, but all the way
A mightie man at armes, and mickle fame
That none in equall armes him matchen might,
His vncouth shield and straunge armes her dismayd,
Ill weares he armes, that nill them vse for Ladies sake.
And deedes of armes aboue all Dames is deemed,
Tho fast her clipping twixt his armes twaine,
That deedes of armes had euer in despaire,
All the braue knights, that doen in armes excell,
Of deeds of armes, which vnto them became,
In sewing deeds of armes, my liues and labours end.
And ranne into her louers armes right fast;
To proue some deedes of armes vpon an equall pere.
Which all good knights, that armes do beare this day,
His armes, which he had vowed to disprofesse,
Yet nould she d'off her weary armes, for feare
And his owne armes when glittering he did spy,
Lightly he clipt her twixt his armes twaine,
Was then assembled, deeds of armes to see:
That bore great sway in armes and chiualrie,
That did those armes and that same scutchion weld,
That oft for her in bloudie armes they fought.
They loued armes, and knighthood did ensew,
To view and deeme the deedes of armes that day;
And equall armes himselfe did forward set.
Broke vp the listes, their armes away to rend;
And gan to treate of deeds of armes abrode,
One in bright armes, with ready speare in rest,
A Painim knight, that well in armes was skild,
The shield and armes well knowne to be the same,
For to haue rent his shield and armes away,
Cambelloes armes therefore he on him threw,
Assembled were their deedes of armes to shew.
Ne was there Knight that euer thought of armes,
That with the praise of armes and cheualrie,
The armes he bore, his speare he gan abase,
That rather seemes, sith knowen armes ye shonne.
Attyr'd in forraine armes and straunge aray:
And shun his mightie strokes, gainst which no armes auayled.
This vgly creature in his armes her snatcht,
He stayed not, but in his armes her bearing
Whilest he in armes her bore; but when she felt
Traind vp in feats of armes and knightlinesse;
And eke through heauie armes, which sore annoyd
Wherein the honor both of Armes ye shame,
I hauing armes then taken, gan auise
Which did in noble deedes of armes excell,
That blame it is to him, that armes profest,
And brawney armes had lost their knowen might,
Expert in battell and in deedes of armes;
And both in armes well traind and throughly tride.
They rose in armes, and all in battell order stood.
To deedes of armes and proofe of cheualrie
All sixe well seene in armes, and prou'd in many a fight.
Full many deedes of armes that day were donne,
There Marinell great deeds of armes did shew;
And rather had to lose, then trie in armes his right.
By law of armes there neede ones right to trie,
And blotted out his armes with falshood blent,
And himselfe baffuld, and his armes vnherst,
And armes dishonour with base villanie,
Through hard aduentures deedes of armes to try,
First she doth them of warlike armes despoile,
And Queene of Amazons, in armes well tride,
Out of her steely armes were flashing seene,
Amongst the which she causd his warlike armes
Ne doffe her armes, though he her much besought.
And armes had borne, but little good could finde,
Of armes has knighthood stolne, yet Knight art none,
Of British armes doest maske thy royall blood,
As glad to heare of armes, the which now she
And practicke vse in armes: ne spared not
And gushed through their armes, that all in gore
In glistering armes right goodly well beseene,
And th'armes and legs of three, to succour him in fight.
When one in armes she saw, began to fly;
Cals for his armes, and arming him withall,
That two more of his armes did fall away,
The vse of armes, and battell quite forgone:
Who when he gaue me armes, in field to fight,
And clasping twixt his armes, her vp did reare
But scorne of armes that hast with guilty hand
Both noble armes and gentle curtesie.
And hauing soone his armes about him dight,
That court'sie doth as well as armes professe,
By thee no knight; which armes impugneth plaine?
The law of armes; yet breake it should againe,
So long as these two armes were able to be wroken.
Assayld, not knowing what to armes doth long.
Or stay till he his armes, which were thereby,
For since the day that armes I first did reare,
Onely the vse of armes, which most I ioy,
I may beare armes, and learne to vse them right;
These goodly gilden armes, which I haue won in fight.
To loue of armes, which in you doth aspire,
Of armes, that if I yet him nigh may reach,
Clad all in gilden armes, with azure band
And borne great sway in armes amongst his peares:
And loued all that did to armes incline.
His warlike armes he had from him vndight:
And in his tender armes her forced vp to stay.
Then vp he tooke her twixt his armes twaine,
Not wont on foote with heauy armes to trace,
And blot of all that armes vppon them take,
That thou for euer doe those armes forsake,
Yet armes or weapon had he none to fight,
Well then him chaunst his heauy armes to want,
Then tooke he vp betwixt his armes twaine
Withouten armes or steede to ride vpon,
Both horse and armes, and what so else to lend,
Those warlike armes, which Calepine whyleare
And streight his combrous armes aside did lay
And him embracing twixt his armes entire,
Renowmed much in armes and derring doe:
And hanging vp his armes and warlike spoyle,
Ne euer armes, ne euer knighthood dare
Those goodly armes, he them away did giue
Hauing his armes and warlike things vndight,
To whom the Priest with naked armes full net
Had traueld still on foot in heauie armes,
And doffing his bright armes, himselfe addrest
Yet holding fast twixt both his armes extended
And in his armes the dreary dying mayd,
Then her embracing twixt her armes twaine,
And all that dreadfull Armie fast gan flye
Or daunt vnequall armies of his foes,
Nations captiued, and huge armies slaine:
Armies of louely lookes, and speeches wise,
Holding in hand a goodly arming sword,
Cals for his armes, and arming him withall,
And looked in: his glistring armor made
But streight her selfe did dight, and armor don;
Them closely into Armorick did beare:
From Armoricke, where long in wretched cace
Well worthy be you of that Armorie,
Whereof there was great store, and armors bright,
Faire Britomart, and that same Armory
That in his armour bare a croslet red.
But ere he could his armour on him dight,
His mightie armour, missing most at need;
His glitterand armour shined farre away,
Both shield, and sword, and armour all he wrought
For as the clashing of an Armour bright,
And through his armour all his bodie seard,
Whose armour all with bloud besprinckled was;
But when as him all in bright armour clad
Who seeing one that shone in armour faire,
And all his armour sprinckled was with bloud,
The waues about, and all his armour swept,
For why should a dead dog be deckt in armour bright?
Adowne so fast, and all his armour steepe,
Vprose Sir Guyon, in bright armour clad,
Ah gentlest knight, that euer armour bore,
And all his armour seem'd of antique mould,
A goodly Armour, and full rich aray,
Where farre away one all in armour bright,
Their garments wet, and weary armour free,
To them appear'd, with shield and armour fit;
These warlike Champions all in armour shine,
That streames of bloud his armour all bedide.
And starting vp, streight for his armour sought:
For all his armour was like saluage weed,
But in his armour layd him downe to rest:
Where when he saw the Prince in armour bright,
Ne any armour could his dint out ward,
And all these knights, which that day armour bore,
And broke his sword in twaine, and all his armour sperst.
Him clad in th'armour of a Pagan knight,
Kept himselfe still in his straunge armour dight.
Commaunded straight his armour to be brought,
Onely his shield and armour, which there lay,
Whom seeing all in armour bright as day,
So hideously vppon his armour bright,
And all his armour did with purple dye;
He wore no armour, ne for none did care,
And all their armours staynd with bloudie gore,
And all his armours readie dight that day,
With those braue armours lying on the ground,
In th'arm-pit full, that through both sides the wound appeard.
With which she wondrous deeds of arms atchieued,
Whom when thou mayst, thou dost of arms despoile,
And catching vp his arms streight to the noise forth past.
Till that his army dry-foot through them yod,
Whiles in the aire their clustring army flies,
And after all an army strong she leau'd,
An army brought, and with him battell fought,
And Aeolus faire daughter Arne hight.
Arose the virgin borne of heauenly brood,
In haste Duessa from her place arose,
Which hauing seene, from thence arose away
She vp arose, resoluing him to find
Which doen, she vp arose with seemely grace,
Then freshly vp arose the doughtie knight,
They all attonce out of their seates arose,
Then vp arose a man of matchlesse might,
Which seeing stout Bunduca, vp arose,
Out of his swowne arose, fresh to contend,
With that, the other likewise vp arose,
Lightly arose out of her wearie bed,
Arose, she bad her charet to be brought,
He vp arose, as halfe in great disdaine,
With that, an hideous storme of winde arose,
The trumpets sounded, and they all arose,
He seeing her depart, arose vp light,
Then vp arose a person of deepe reach,
Would haue the passion hid, and vp arose withall.
They both arose, and at him loudly cryde,
He vp arose, how euer liefe or loth,
Hymen iO Hymen, dauncing all around,
And Nereus crownes with cups; his mates him pledg around.
Teaching the Satyres, which her sat around,
Three miles it might be easie heard around,
The neighbour woods around with hollow murmur ring.
And ouerflowed all the field around;
The light-foot Squire her quickly turnd around,
That all her goodly garments staind around,
Drawing to him the eyes of all around,
The day that first doth lead the yeare around;
To bud out faire, and her sweet smels throw all around.
That nought but desert wildernesse shew'd all around.
And was with dread and horrour compassed around.
Could gathered be through all the world around,
Like highest heauen compassed around,
Thus being entred, they behold around
Saue Beares, Lions, & Buls, which romed them around.
And sore beset on euery side around,
But restlesse walketh all the world around,
So like a wheele around they runne from old to new.
In homely wize, and wald with sods around,
And with like labour walke the world around,
Was drawne vpon the waues, that fomed him around.
Eftsoones he gan to gather vp around
And answering their wearie turnes around,
Chasing the gentle Calepine around,
And euery litle limbe he searcht around,
His fleecie flocke vpon the playnes around,
Tho wrapping vp her wrethed sterne arownd,
Adornd with fruitfull Oliues all arownd,
Which flowing long and thick, her cloth'd arownd,
About their Lady first they flockt arownd,
Whiles th'altars fume with frankincense arownd,
With rich array and costly arras dight:
With royall arras and resplendent gold.
That was with royall arras richly dight,
With costly clothes of Arras and of Toure,
With goodly arras of great maiesty,
All which in that faire arras was most liuely writ.
For not with arras made in painefull loome,
Arraught the rule, and from their father drew,
(A sory sight) arraung'd in battell new,
So both to battell fierce arraunged arre,
With rich array and costly arras dight:
With royall robes and gorgeous array,
And stroue to match, in royall rich array,
In sun-bright armes, and battailous array:
In ashes and sackcloth he did array
And match his brother proud in battailous array.
Both clad in colours like, and like array,
By the faire lockes, and fowly did array,
The cause of their array, and truce for to desire.
The bridegromes state, the brides most rich array,
They were an hundred knights of that array;
Sixe of thy fellowes of the best array,
First, that sir Artegall should him array,
Presenting him with all the rich array,
and see her rich array.
For neuer saw they there the like array.
Which will her cause in battailous array
Flocking together in confusde array,
Sir Artegall, in battailous array
When Artegall she saw in that array,
Standing alone on foot, in foule array:
That from henceforth in batteilous array
When Calidore in seemly good array
He passed forth with her in faire array,
Seeing his royall vsage and array,
Met her in such misseeming foule array;
That in this wize, and this vnmeete array,
And afterwards of all her rich array;
So farre doth she in beautyfull array,
In loues and gentle iollities arrayd,
Eftsoones they saw an hideous hoast arrayd,
Vnto the barre, whereas she was arrayned:
Faire harbour that them seemes; so in they entred arre.
To all, that in the wide deepe wandring arre:
So both to battell fierce arraunged arre,
That of your selfe ye thus berobbed arre,
And at the point two stings in-fixed arre,
O miserable men, that to him subiect arre.
The brother of Cymochles, both which arre
Sir Knight, that thus ye now subdewed arre:
From this renowmed Prince deriued arre,
That in the Realme ere long they stronger arre,
Faire Ladies, that to loue captiued arre,
But ah my rimes too rude and rugged arre,
Which when to ripenesse due they growen arre,
And eeke this wallet at your backe arreare,
Were hard behind, her readie to arrest:
That all his senses did full soone arrest:
Arrested all that courtly company,
And there arresting, readie way did yield,
The charge, which God doth vnto me arret,
And vnto each a Bulwarke did arret,
And a quicke mouing Spirit did arret
But after that the Iudges did arret her
And at his first arriuall, them began
Of their arriuall: wherewith troubled sore,
Arriu'd, where they in erth their fruitles bloud had sown.
As weather-beaten ship arriu'd on happie shore.
Where when the knight arriu'd, he was right well
So soone as Mammon there arriu'd, the dore
Driuen by fatall error, here arriu'd,
Soone as they bene arriu'd vpon the brim
He on the bancke arriu'd with mickle paine,
Had vndertaken after her, arriu'd,
Till they arriu'd, whereas their purpose they did plot.
And that same gentle Squire arriu'd in place,
Now when as Artegall arriu'd in place,
Loe now, right noble knights, arriu'd ye bee
When these two stranger knights arriu'd in place,
And there arriu'd againe, whence forth he set,
Whenas these Knights arriu'd, they wist not where nor how.
Arriu'd in place, their bondslaues for to buy;
By you, when ye arriue in that same place;
Supposd to be. They do arriue anone,
Vntill they nigh vnto that Gulfe arriue,
Thence passing forth, they shortly do arriue,
At last in Latium he did arriue,
Till they arriue at their last ruinous decay.
That none can there arriue without an hoste:
Arriued there, the little house they fill,
Gan shut the dore. By this arriued there
Arriued there they passed in forth right;
Was writ Sans ioy, they new arriued find:
The wyld woodgods arriued in the place,
And throwne about the cliffs. Arriued there,
Arriued there, the dore they find fast lockt;
There when the Elfin knight arriued was,
Being arriued, where that champion stout
And well arriued are, (high God be blest)
And soone arriued, where that sad pourtraict
How in that place straunge knight arriued late,
Till they arriued in that pleasant Ile,
And soone arriued on the shallow sand,
